services.description: Fixed metal brackets and wires used to gradually straighten teeth.
Similar to metal braces, but with clear or tooth-colored brackets for a less noticeable appearance.
Braces placed on the inside (tongue side) of the teeth, hidden from view.
Removable, clear trays used to gradually shift teeth without wires or brackets.
Braces that use a sliding mechanism to hold the archwire, resulting in less friction and potentially faster treatment.
Custom-made devices used after braces or aligners to keep teeth in their new position.
Devices used to widen the upper jaw, often used for children to create more space for teeth alignment.
Appliances used in children to hold space for permanent teeth after baby teeth are lost prematurely.
Devices used to correct bite issues, such as overbites, by repositioning the jaw.
Small rubber bands used with braces to improve bite alignment by applying extra pressure to teeth.
An external device used to guide the growth of the jaw and improve bite alignment in severe cases.
Small titanium screws inserted into the jawbone to provide additional support for tooth movement.
Surgical procedures to correct severe jaw misalignment, often used in conjunction with braces.
Clear, removable retainers designed to maintain teeth position after orthodontic treatment.
Appliances used to treat bite problems such as crossbites, underbites, or overbites.
Small rubber or metal devices placed between teeth to create space before braces are applied.
Soft wax used to cover brackets or wires that irritate the inside of the mouth during braces treatment.
Small chewable devices used to help seat aligners properly for better fit and effectiveness.
Used to stabilize teeth in cases of trauma or severe malocclusion.
Techniques or devices used to speed up tooth movement during orthodontic treatment.
Professional treatment to lighten and brighten discolored or stained teeth.
Thin, custom-made shells (porcelain or composite) placed over the front of teeth to improve appearance.
Application of tooth-colored resin to repair chipped, cracked, or discolored teeth.
Caps placed over damaged or decayed teeth to restore their shape, size, and appearance.
Custom-made fillings (often porcelain or gold) used for larger cavities or damage that traditional fillings can't fix.
Clear, removable trays used to straighten teeth without traditional braces.
Traditional or ceramic braces used to straighten crooked or misaligned teeth.
Procedure to reshape or remove excess gum tissue to improve the appearance of a 'gummy smile.'
Titanium posts surgically placed in the jawbone to replace missing teeth, topped with a natural-looking crown.
A comprehensive plan combining multiple cosmetic treatments to achieve the perfect smile.
Combination of cosmetic and restorative procedures to improve the health, function, and appearance of the entire mouth.
Minor adjustments to the shape of teeth by removing small amounts of enamel to improve appearance.
Tooth-colored fillings used to repair cavities or damage, providing a natural look compared to metal fillings.
Dental prosthetics used to replace missing teeth by anchoring artificial teeth to adjacent natural teeth.
Partial crowns used to cover a damaged portion of a tooth without completely capping it.
Fixed prosthetics that bridge the gap created by one or more missing teeth.
Dentures designed for a more natural appearance, providing function and aesthetics for patients with missing teeth.
Small decorative gems or diamonds placed on the surface of the teeth for aesthetic appeal.
Advanced teeth whitening using laser technology for faster and more effective results.
Used around the mouth to smooth wrinkles and enhance the overall appearance of a smile.
Removal of superficial stains and discoloration by gently buffing the enamel.
Corrective surgery to improve facial balance, address jaw irregularities, and enhance the appearance of the face.
Routine cleaning to remove plaque, tartar, and stains from teeth, usually done every 6 months.
A more intensive cleaning procedure for patients with gum disease, involving the removal of plaque and tartar from below the gumline and smoothing the tooth roots.
An initial cleaning to remove heavy plaque and tartar buildup in patients who have not had regular cleanings and are at risk for periodontal disease.
Ongoing cleaning for patients with gum disease, performed at more frequent intervals than regular cleanings to prevent progression of the disease.
A cleaning technique that uses a high-pressure jet of air, water, and an abrasive agent to remove stains and plaque from teeth.
Application of fluoride to strengthen tooth enamel and help prevent cavities after a cleaning.
Laser treatment used to reduce the bacterial load in the gums and prevent gum disease, often done alongside regular cleaning.
Use of ultrasonic tools that vibrate at high frequency to break up plaque, tartar, and stains more efficiently than manual scaling.
A cosmetic cleaning procedure to remove surface stains and make teeth smooth and shiny after plaque and tartar removal.
Targeted removal of external stains caused by food, drinks, or smoking through scaling, polishing, or air polishing.
A preventive measure to apply a protective coating on the chewing surfaces of molars after cleaning, reducing the risk of cavities.
A diagnostic service to analyze the levels of harmful bacteria in saliva, aiding in personalized cleaning and treatment plans.
Application of antimicrobial agents to reduce bacterial infection in the gums, often used in conjunction with deep cleaning.
A cleaning service that targets gum health, helping to remove bacteria and prevent periodontal disease.
Education on brushing, flossing, and maintaining oral hygiene at home to support the results of professional teeth cleaning.
Application of fluoride to strengthen tooth enamel and help prevent the formation of cavities.
Protective coating applied to the chewing surfaces of molars to seal deep grooves and prevent cavities.
A topical solution that helps prevent and halt the progression of existing cavities by hardening the tooth surface.
A restorative procedure to treat cavities by filling the decayed area of the tooth with materials such as composite resin, amalgam, or porcelain.
Tooth-colored fillings used to restore decayed teeth and blend with the natural tooth color.
Routine professional cleanings that remove plaque and tartar to prevent cavities and gum disease.
Similar to dental sealants, applied to the natural grooves of teeth where cavities commonly form.
Use of xylitol-based products like gums and mints that help reduce the risk of cavities by neutralizing acids and bacteria in the mouth.
Application of chemicals or compounds that slow down or inhibit the formation of cavities, such as fluoride varnishes and rinses.
Use of calcium phosphate and fluoride products to remineralize weakened enamel and prevent early cavity formation.
Analysis of saliva to determine bacterial levels and other factors that could increase cavity risk, allowing for tailored preventive care.
Advice on reducing sugary and acidic foods to lower the risk of cavities.
Protective devices worn during sleep to prevent tooth grinding (bruxism), which can wear down enamel and make teeth more susceptible to cavities.
Use of special gum containing casein phosphopeptide-amorphous calcium phosphate to help protect enamel and reduce the risk of cavities.
Use of chlorhexidine or fluoride-based mouthwashes to reduce harmful bacteria that cause cavities.
Guidance on proper brushing and flossing techniques to remove plaque and reduce cavity risk.
Early dental checkups, usually recommended by age 1, to assess the health of a baby's gums and teeth.
Routine teeth cleaning and plaque removal for children to prevent cavities and gum disease.
Application of fluoride to strengthen enamel and help prevent cavities in children's teeth.
Protective coatings applied to the chewing surfaces of molars to prevent cavities in kids.
Treatment of cavities using tooth-colored composite resin or silver amalgam fillings.
Safe, low-radiation imaging to detect cavities, monitor teeth development, and identify any dental issues.
Custom-made devices used to hold space for permanent teeth when baby teeth are lost prematurely.
Treatment for infected or damaged tooth pulp to save a primary (baby) tooth.
A non-invasive treatment to stop the progression of cavities and prevent further decay in young children.
Early orthodontic evaluation and treatment, such as space maintainers or braces, to guide the proper development of teeth and jaws.
Removal of decayed, damaged, or overcrowded baby teeth when necessary.
Treatment for dental emergencies such as toothaches, broken teeth, or knocked-out teeth.
Custom-made mouthguards to protect children's teeth and gums during sports activities.
Specialized techniques to help children, especially those with dental anxiety, feel comfortable and relaxed during dental visits.
Safe sedation used to help children stay calm and comfortable during dental procedures.
Monitoring and evaluating children's bite development to detect early signs of misalignment or jaw issues.
Guidance and tips for parents to help children stop thumb sucking or using pacifiers, which can affect teeth alignment.
Education on proper oral hygiene habits for kids and advice for parents on how to care for their child's teeth.
Advice on healthy eating habits and limiting sugary foods and drinks to prevent cavities in children.
A minimally invasive treatment applied to vulnerable areas of teeth to prevent cavities, similar to sealants but used for more advanced protection.

services.serviceName: Lip and Tongue Tie Assessments and Treatment
services.description: Evaluation and correction of lip or tongue ties in infants and children to improve breastfeeding, speech, and dental health.
Referrals to an orthodontist for braces or other corrective treatment as needed.
Fun and educational programs to teach kids the importance of oral health and how to maintain a healthy smile.
Removal of damaged, decayed, or impacted teeth, including wisdom teeth extractions.
Surgical removal of impacted or misaligned wisdom teeth to prevent infection, pain, or damage to adjacent teeth.
Surgical placement of titanium posts into the jawbone to replace missing teeth, which are later topped with crowns.
Procedure to build up or restore bone in the jaw, often required before placing dental implants.
Procedure to add bone to the upper jaw near the molars and premolars by lifting the sinus membrane, often done before dental implants.
Surgery to remove the tip of the root of a tooth and surrounding infected tissue, often performed after a failed root canal.
Surgery to correct jaw misalignment, improve bite function, and treat issues such as sleep apnea or facial trauma.
Surgical removal of the frenum (the small tissue that connects the lips, tongue, or cheeks to the gums), often to treat tongue-tie or lip-tie.
Surgical procedures to treat severe temporomandibular joint disorders when conservative treatments fail.
Biopsy of suspicious lesions or tissue in the mouth to detect oral cancer, followed by surgical removal of cancerous growths if necessary.
Surgical removal of cysts or benign tumors in the mouth, jaw, or face.
Treatment for facial injuries, such as broken jaws or fractured facial bones, to restore function and appearance.
Surgical drainage of a dental abscess, which is a collection of pus caused by a bacterial infection in the tooth or gum.
Procedure to rebuild the natural contour of the gums and jawbone after tooth loss or bone resorption.
Grafting of soft tissue to treat gum recession, improve gum health, or enhance the appearance of the gums.
Surgical exposure of impacted teeth (commonly canines) to aid in orthodontic treatment for proper alignment.
Surgical preparation of the mouth for dentures, including reshaping the jaw or removing excess tissue.
Surgical smoothing or reshaping of the jawbone after tooth extraction, often in preparation for dentures or implants.
Surgical procedures to correct cleft lip or palate in children, improving function and appearance.
Surgical treatment for obstructive sleep apnea, which may involve removing excess tissue in the throat or repositioning the jaw.
Procedures to enhance the appearance of the face, such as chin augmentation or reconstructive surgery after trauma.
Removal or reshaping of gum tissue to treat gum disease or improve aesthetics.
A cosmetic procedure to correct a 'gummy smile' by repositioning the upper lip to show less gum when smiling.
